awd_titl_txt: Multiscale Simulation and Experimental Study of Thermotransport in Binary Alloys
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY: When large temperature gradients are present in metallic alloys, compositional gradients and phase transformations can occur, potentially leading to mechanical failure or undesirable changes in properties. This effect, known as thermotransport, is not well understood at the atomic scale for solids. Currently, there are no theoretical approaches to predict the relevant transport parameters. The PIs propose to elucidate thermotranport using phase-field modeling in conjunction with a multiscale computational approach based on atomic-scale simulation that includes molecular-dynamics and kinetic Monte-Carlo simulations. To compute key transport parameters, the local free energy profiles for vacancy diffusion in the presence of a temperature gradient will be computed. This approach enables direct computation of dissipative processes relevant to transport. Theoretical predictions will be validated using the results of experiments on Cu-Ni and Ni-Al binary alloys.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: In materials relevant for many applications, including nuclear-fuel alloys, interconnects for electronic circuits, and alloys for gas-turbine engines, the relentless drive towards higher efficiencies, increased temperatures, and smaller dimensions results in very large temperature gradients during operation. As a result of large temperature gradients, constituent atoms tend to be redistributed, leading to composition gradients and phase transformations. This effect, known as thermotransport, results in property changes in engineered components. For example, constituent redistribution in turbine blades can lead to mechanical failure. In this project, the PIs will use simulation at the atomic and continuum scales, along with experiments, to elucidate thermotransport in Ni-Al and Cu-Ni binary alloys. The ability to predict and understand thermotransport is expected to have a major impact on the stability of alloys used in high-temperature environments. Ph.D. students will be trained in the experimental and computational studies. Computational tools will be accessible to students in the statewide Florida Society for Materials Simulation. A summer 'Materials Camp' for K-12 students and teachers, including students from groups under-represented in science careers, will be hosted. The results will be made available to the community and integrated into commercial software packages for the simulation of diffusion in multicomponent alloys.

This objective of this project was to elucidate thermodiffusion in binary-alloy metals by using a combination of computational approaches and experiments. Thermodiffusion, also often called the Ludwig-Soret effect, refers to the observation that in the presence of a temperature gradient, the individual components of an alloy tend to segregate. In a two-component metal alloy, for example, one component will tend to be driven "up" the temperature gradient, and the other component driven "down" the temperature gradient. This has significant implications in technology, especially for applications with large temperature gradients, including electronic devices, turbine blades, and nuclear fuels .

The intellectual merit of the proposal is that the researchers identified and verified a new approach tow compute the relevant parameters that describe thermodiffusion. Namely, a method was developed to compute the heat of transport, which describes the amount of heat transported diuring interdiffusion. The main challenge is that in a crystalline metal, the process occurs too slowly to observe in a "brute force" calculation. To address this problem, a method was developed to compute the work done in dragging an atom through an interdiffusion event in the presence of a temperature gradient. The computed work was related to the heat of transport. The method was verified by application to thermodiffusion of hydrogen in a palladium lattice, which occurs very rapidly and hence the heat of transport can be computed using different approaches. Using the verified method, the heat of transport for vacancies in a single-component metal was also elucidated. This is one of the main outcomes of the proposed work. Specifically, we have now have the tools to compute vacancy-mediated thermodiffusion in binary metals, where the diffusion rate is extremely slow.

The newly-developed method, in combination with "brute force" methods applied to binary metal liquids and similar systems, has also lead to significant physical insight into the physical mechanism of thermodiffusion, including insight into what determines the sign of the heat of transport. This is another important intellectual merit of the project. It was established that stress/pressure changes along the direction of the mass transport dominate the heat of transport. When atoms undergo a diffusion event, their local stress component is different from an atom not diffusing.  It was also established that the important quantities establishing the direction of thermodiffusion is connected to the partial pressures of the two components. Another important outcome was the development of a clear physical picture for why high-mass atoms tend to diffuse down a temperature gradient, and low-mass atoms tend to diffuse up a temperature gradient. This trend has been noted previously in experiment and simulations, but until now had no clear physical picture. Finally, it was demonstrated that existing theories of thermodiffusion in liquids are incomplete. Spefically, it was demonstrated that eixisting phenomenological theories applied to liquids and crystalline materials, where transport is mediated by vacancies, are inconsistent. A path forward to a theory has been identified as a result of the project, which was indicated by the realization, based on computational results, that transport in a liquid also occurs by a mechanism very similar to the concept of a vacancy in a crystal.
